docs.lead_paragraph: Jump up and down, roar like Pavarotti, plunge into an ice-cold shower or, in emergencies, try all three at once. People do not lack for theories about how to stay awake, and there is certainly no shortage of options for the millions of cramming college students, occasional insomniacs and others overloaded by work, family and life who simply need to keep their eyes open for a few extra hours.

headline.main: When a Nap Is Not on the Program

docs.abstract: Dr James K Wyatt, Rush University Medical Center, Chicago, sleep researcher, conducts study showing that caffeine, which is most widely used stimulant, can help people function for periods of time without proper sleep; holds that small regular doses of caffeine over time are most effective, but cannot ultimately replace sleep; other drugs used by people to stay awake discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Jump up and down, roar like Pavarotti, plunge into an ice-cold shower or, in emergencies, try all three at once.     People do not lack for theories about how to stay awake, and there is certainly no shortage of options for the millions of cramming...

docs.lead_paragraph: The temptation to psychoanalyze public figures from the safety of an armchair is a strong one, perhaps stronger for those with professional credentials. Freud plumbed the psyche of Leonardo da Vinci, tracing the artist's homosexuality to his erotic attachment to his mother and his father's absence.

headline.main: The Perils of Putting National Leaders on the Couch

docs.abstract: Dr Sally Satel essay criticizes of psychologists who write biographical books in which they analyze political figures; holds that without conducting psychological examination writers are merely using hindsight and generalizations to support theories of behavior; debates effectiveness of applied psychoanalysis as tool to explain behavior even with full patient evaluation (S)
docs.snippet: The temptation to psychoanalyze public figures from the safety of an armchair is a strong one, perhaps stronger for those with professional credentials.    Freud plumbed the psyche of Leonardo da Vinci, tracing the artist's homosexuality to his...

docs.lead_paragraph: People with painful injuries like serious burns often report experiencing great relief when using virtual reality programs. But it has been unclear whether this is merely a matter of perception. Now a new study, published in the journal NeuroReport, has found that the improvement is measurable and substantial.

headline.main: Taking Your Mind Off the Pain

docs.abstract: Dr Hunter G Hoffman of University of Washington leads study that finds participation in virtual reality programs can significantly reduce individual's perception of pain; study, published in NeuroReport, found significantly reduced brain activity in five pain centers during reality program, in essense distracting people from feeling pain; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: People with painful injuries like serious burns often report experiencing great relief when using virtual reality programs. But it has been unclear whether this is merely a matter of perception.     Now a new study, published in the journal...

docs.lead_paragraph: The start of summer is a busy time for Dr. Robert S. Gotlin, director of orthopedic and sports rehabilitation at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. That is when his waiting room swells with patients who want to see him about their knees. ''The complaints of knee pain are directly proportional to the change in seasons,'' Dr. Gotlin said. ''People run more in the spring and summer, and the pain usually comes from upping the mileage. It's hard not to overdo it when the weather is so nice.''

headline.main: Novel Remedies for the Aching Knees of Summer

docs.abstract: Dr Robert S Gotlin, Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan orthopedic and sports rehabilitation director, holds that knee pain will likely eclipse back pain as primary physical problem seen by sports medicine physicians; incidents of knee problems increase as weather warms and people become more physically active; basic home remedy of icing and heat along with over-the-counter anti-inflamatories is suggested as starting off place for helping knee injuries; other remedies and therapies for knee problems, such as use of supplements, injections and topical creams, discussed; surgery is seen as last resort remedy for knee injury; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The start of summer is a busy time for Dr. Robert S. Gotlin, director of orthopedic and sports rehabilitation at the Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. That is when his waiting room swells with patients who want to see him about their knees.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: July, popular belief has it, is a perilous time to get sick. Come July 1 every year, thousands of newly minted medical school graduates flood teaching hospitals to begin residency programs. They have lots of enthusiasm, anxiety and book knowledge -- and extremely little clinical experience.

headline.main: Their Coats Are White, but Their Hands Are Green

docs.abstract: Popular belief that hospital care is not as good in July when new interns arrive is not substantiated in research studies; Drs William A Barry and Gary E Rosenthal of University of Iowa Hospitals and Clinics in Iowa City studied files of over 48,000 patients admitted to 28 hospital intensive care units in Ohio and found no month to month difference in lengths of stay or mortality rates; there is some evidence that psychiatric patients are at greater risk of problems during switch over from established therapist to new resident for care; photo (M)
docs.snippet: July, popular belief has it, is a perilous time to get sick.    Come July 1 every year, thousands of newly minted medical school graduates flood teaching hospitals to begin residency programs. They have lots of enthusiasm, anxiety and book knowledge...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Caring for Your Teenager,'' by Dr. Donald E. Greydanus, editor, and Philip Bashe. Bantam Books, $18.95. ''Living Simply with Children,'' by Marie Sherlock. Three Rivers Press, $12.95. ''The Happiest Toddler on the Block,'' by Dr. Harvey Karp and Paula Spencer. Bantam, $22.95. It is hard to be a parent, let alone a good one. Children not only get expected and unexpected ailments, but they use drugs and tobacco, develop eating disorders, have to cope with death and divorce. And they know their rights.
docs.abstract: Dr Donald E Greydanus and Philip Bashe book Caring for Your Teenager gives guide to help parents navigate one of most difficult times in child's life; Marie Sherlock book Living Simply with Children explores better quantity time for parents and children and presents ways to reclaim simplier family life; Dr Harvey Karp and Paula Spencer book The Happiest Toddler on the Block compares pre-schoolers to stone-age men and suggests being patient and supportive of toddler's evolution into older child; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Women who want to breast-feed are often discouraged from giving their babies pacifiers on the theory that the sucking action needed to use a pacifier, or even a bottle, is different from that required to breast-feed. But a new study finds that at least among premature babies, pacifier use does not seem to reduce the odds of successful breast-feeding.
docs.abstract: Carmel T Collins of Women and Children's Hospital in South Australia leads study that shows pacifier use does not impede babies ability to breast feed; findings are published in BMJ, British medical journal; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Women who want to breast-feed are often discouraged from giving their babies pacifiers on the theory that the sucking action needed to use a pacifier, or even a bottle, is different from that required to breast-feed.    But a new study finds that at...

docs.lead_paragraph: I remember well the days when women were told to gain no more than 24 pounds in the nine months of pregnancy. I remember, too, being terrified at my routine obstetrical visit the month I gained seven pounds, not realizing at the time that I was carrying twins. Some women took the restrictions on weight gain to an extreme and failed to gain enough to produce a full-size baby.
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses potential complications of being overweight or obese at start of pregnancy; National Academy of Sciences Institute of Medicine recommendations for weight gain during pregnancy given; Dr Laura E Riley, Massachusetts General Hospital obstetrician and American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists committee on obstetric practice chairwoman, stresses need to get weight under control prior to getting pregnant; risks to mother of being overweight while pregnant and risks to unborn child described; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: I remember well the days when women were told to gain no more than 24 pounds in the nine months of pregnancy. I remember, too, being terrified at my routine obstetrical visit the month I gained seven pounds, not realizing at the time that I was...

docs.lead_paragraph: A mother's love is like a drug, psychologists say, a potent substance that cements the parent-infant bond and has a profound impact on later development. But scientists have known little about how early mothering affects an infant biologically. If it is like a drug, what kind of drug?

headline.main: Addicted to Mother's Love: It's Biology, Stupid

docs.abstract: Recent studies suggest direct relationship between early mothering and caregiving and later child development; Dr Francesca R D'Amato, CNR Institute of Neuroscience researcher, leads study on gene that inhibits separation anxiety in mice; study, published in journal Science, observed mice that did not develop bonds with mothers because they lacked genetic foundation to feel comfort; supports concept that maternal support acts as 'opiate,' which then tightens attachment bond with mother; other studies that support maternal attachment and child development described (M)
docs.snippet: A mother's love is like a drug, psychologists say, a potent substance that cements the parent-infant bond and has a profound impact on later development.     But scientists have known little about how early mothering affects an infant biologically....

docs.lead_paragraph: Laurie Coots, a marketing executive who flies to meetings in other countries twice a week, spent years trying to conquer sleepless nights and chronic jet lag. But nothing worked, she says, and every day was a struggle to stay awake. ''It was debilitating,'' said Ms. Coots, 46, who is from Los Angeles. ''I couldn't give an effective presentation because I was always shaky and nervous from being amped up on caffeine and stimulants.''
docs.abstract: Modafinil, drug manufactured by Cephalon and sold as Provigil, enables people to go for extended periods of time without sleep; modafinil, which was first discovered in 1970's as treatment for narcolepsy, is now approved by Food and Drug Administration for additional use in treating obstructive sleep apnea and as aid for other sleep problems; off-label uses for drug continue to grow; theories on how modafinil works on brain are described, but scientists are uncertain how drug actually works; concerns over abuse of modafinil discussed; photo; drawings (L)
docs.snippet: Laurie Coots, a marketing executive who flies to meetings in other countries twice a week, spent years trying to conquer sleepless nights and chronic jet lag. But nothing worked, she says, and every day was a struggle to stay awake.    ''It was...
